data.title: Test Settings
data.body:
- [x] Windows - **@jrieken**
- [x] macOS - **@isidorn**
- [x] Linux - **@joaomoreno**

Complexity: 4

## No Workspace

- Settings are read and applied from Default / User settings. Make sure user settings override defaults.
- Update User settings and verify the update.
- Update settings using User actions like `Toggling Sidebar Visibility` and verify updates

## Folder Workspace

- Settings are read and applied from Default / User / Workspace settings. Make sure workspace settings override user settings and default settings.
- Workspace settings come from `.vscode` folder under the folder.
- Update User settings and Workspace settings and verify the updates.
- Update settings using User actions and verify updates
-- Have `files.associations` setting in Workspace scope and try to update the file association using the language mode on the status bar. Verify workspace setting is updated.

## Multi folder Workspace

- Open a workspace with multiple folders 

Source of Settings are 
- Defaults come from Default settings
- User settings come from User settings file
- Workspace settings come from Settings file of first root folder excluding Folder scoped settings
- Folder settings come from Settings file of root folders excluding Workspace scoped settings.

Supported resource scoped settings in Core 
```
editor.*
files.exclude
files.trimTrailingWhitespace
files.insertFinalNewLine
files.encoding
files.autoGuessEncoding
files.watcherExclude
search.exclude
```
Rest are Workbench settings.

Verify:

- Default setting is applied to all folders unless overridden
- User setting is applied to all folders unless overridden
- Workspace setting is applied to all folders unless overridden
- Workspace settings show non setting properties dimmed.
- Folder settings are applied only to the resources under folders.
- Folder settings show not supported workbench settings as dimmed with an info icon
- Default settings shows only default folder settings when folder settings are opened.

## Test Configuration API

- Verify that you can define a configuration scoped to `resource` or `workbench` using `configuration` contribution point. E.g.
```json
"configuration": {
            "type": "object",
            "properties": {
                "testExtension.resourceConfiguration": {
                    "type": "boolean",
                    "scope": "resource"
                }
            }
        }
```

Remember to change `engines.vscode` to `*` and running `npm install` to get the latest `vscode.d.ts`. Then:

```ts
const configuration = vscode.workspace.getConfiguration('testExtension', vscode.window.activeTextEditor.document.uri);

// Verify the methods on configuration object are working as expected
configuration.get('resourceConfiguration');
configuration.inspect('resourceConfiguration');
configuration.update('resourceConfiguration', false, vscode.ConfigurationTarget.WorkspaceFolder)
```


- Verify you can read and write settings correctly in all kinds of workspaces. 

### Configuration API behaviour in Empty workspace

When configuration is asked with or without a resource
- There will be no workspace and folder settings.
- Inspect returns undefined for workspace and folder values always
- Writing into workspace or folder settings results to an error.

### Configuration API behaviour in Folder workspace

When configuration is asked with or without a resource
- There will be no folder settings.
- Inspect returns undefined for folder values always
- Writing into folder settings results to an error.

### Configuration API behaviour in Multi Folder workspace

When configuration is asked for a resource

- Inspect returns values for all targets unless undefined.
- You can only write `resource` scoped setting into folder. Writing `workbench` scoped setting results to an error.

When configuration is not asked for a resource

- Inspect returns undefined for folder values always
- Writing into folder settings results to an error.

data.title: Visual Studio Code not working on Windows 7
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise Service Pack 1 (64-bit)

I have never been able to run any version of VSCode on my work computer. I have tried several recommended methods but none succeeded. I have verified that .NET 4.5.2 is installed. 

Reproduced the problem under following: 
* Downloaded VSCodeSetup-x64-1.14.2.exe and ran setup. Setup terminated at some point without leaving any message. All files seemed to be copied to the installation folder. Launching code.cmd produced no result. Only a blank command prompt popped up and disappeared.  
* Downloaded VSCode-win32-x64-1.14.2.zip and extracted contents. Again, launching code.cmd produced no results leaving no traces (no error, dump file, event log etc.) 
* Tried insiders-build without any success
* Tried 32-bit versions but the outcome did not change.
* Tried --disable-extensions and --disable-gpu options without any success.
* Tried --version, --verbose and --help options to extract some output on the command line. Nothing happened.
* Also tried version 1.12.2 but no changes.

Note: Checked AppData\Roaming\Code folder. It is empty.

data.title: Fail early when electron-mksnapshot comes in the wrong version
data.body:
The version of `electron-mksnapshot` we are using must be in sync with the electron version we are using. This requirement is not obvious and not enforced when running the tool. The result is an invalid snapshot and a brick-build.

fyi @Tyriar @joaomoreno

data.title: ConfigurationUpdateEvent should have sourceConfig.launch if launch.json deleted

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I know you wanted to refactor this, but currently if a user edits a `launch.json` the ConfigurationUpdateEvent correctly has `event.sourceConfig.launch`.
However if the user deletes the `launch.json` another configuration update event is recieved however the `event.sourceConfig.launch` is missing.

If we decide to continue supporting this I believe that in both cases we should send out the `event.sourceConfig.launch`.

data.title: Syntax coloring isn't working when function signature is spread across multiple lines
Smoke test: Failed to create autodetected launch.json
data.body:
See TFS build id 30914 for details.

**Failed test:**
 3) Smoke Test Suite Debugging JavaScript autodetects program attribute for launch.json
**Other tests impacted by this failure:**
 4) Smoke Test Suite Git verifies current changes are picked up by Git viewlet

Seems like Node.js debug environment configuration failed to create launch.json file. I've tried to manually perform test steps, and I wasn't able to get even to debug environment selection on Windows (pressing 'Configure' gear button in Debug viewlet did not give any result with the following error in Chromium console:
`TypeError: Cannot read property 'openConfigFile' of undefined`.

data.title: Smoke test: Failed to change user settings configuration
data.body:
See TFS build id 30914.

This caused the following tests to fail:
1) Smoke Test Suite Configuration and views turns off editor line numbers and verifies the live change
2) Smoke Test Suite CSS verifies that warning becomes an error once setting changed

Seems that it did not type in the editor due to some problems. Could be because wrong element focus because we have new header text in the editor 'Place your settings here to override the Default' or editor was not editable.

data.title: Got Node process error: Error: spawn npm ENOENT when debug node.js
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: windows 7
- node.js Version: 7.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. F5

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No


===================

I try to debug `node.js` in VScode, then get error is 

```
    npm run-script server 
    Node process error: Error: spawn npm ENOENT
```

, and my `launch.json` is:

```
{
  // Use IntelliSense to learn about possible Node.js debug attributes.
  // Hover to view descriptions of existing attributes.
  // For more information, visit: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=830387
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Launch via NPM",
      "runtimeExecutable": "npm",
      "protocol": "inspector",
      "runtimeArgs": [
        "run-script",
        "server"
      ],
      "port": 5858
    }
  ]
}

```

and if I change protocol to legacy, I'll get another error

```
    Unable to connect to the runtime through the "legacy" protocol; Consider using the "inspector" protocol (timeout after 10,000 milliseconds).
```

The gif here under shows what the issue is, and how to reproduce it.
![2017-07-25_14-17-20](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6302961/28608076-376bb338-71df-11e7-8828-ee83d289a294.gif)

data.title: Request: Close working tree diff when a file is staged
data.body:
Personally, I like to view the working tree diffs before staging a file (by clicking the unstaged file in the git pane). After staging the file, the diffs disappear, and the diff tab stays open.

Given that after staging a file the diff tab displays only the file itself, it is useless after staging the file, and I frequently end up closing these. It would be nice if either these diffs closed automatically or if they switched to index diffs so that the diff is still shown (or maybe have an option between doing those two).

data.title: JS linter randomly kicks in, even though it's disabled
data.body:

```json
{
  "javascript.validate.enable": false,
  "typescript.validate.enable": false
}
```

after editing a bunch of files, the JS linter randomly kicks in on random open files:

![screen shot 2017-07-25 at 4 29 46 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4400726/28598148-8c4bf860-7156-11e7-8784-422174610827.png)

Reloading the window temporarily fixes the issue.
